I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support implementation of the 
Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Integrated Trade Agenda (CITA) 2030 by 
enhancing the capacity of customs agencies and the CAREC Customs Cooperation Committee 
(CCC) to better respond to the rapidly evolving trade environment in CAREC countries and 
increasing private sector demand for better services.1 In particular, the TA will help expand trade 
through adoption of more open trade policies, building customs-to-customs cooperation, and 
strengthening  institutions  for  trade  through  increased  public–private  sector  dialogue  and 
cooperation. 
 
2.  The TA is aligned with CAREC long-term strategic priorities, where trade is a priority 
operational cluster, and with Asian Development Bank (ADB) corporate regional cooperation and 
integration (RCI) operational directions for 2016–2020.2 The TA builds on past ADB support and 
responds to the CCC’s new, emerging needs to help further reform, modernize national trade 
facilitation environments, and strengthen intraregional trade among CAREC countries.3  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  CAREC  countries’  national  development  strategies  focus  on  expanding  trade  and 
improving competitiveness to unleash the untapped trade potential of the region, as seen in (i) 
Uzbekistan’s recent opening up and (ii) reforms to support economic diversification, particularly 
export diversification, by expanding trade in non-energy and resource-intensive sectors. Yet in 
2018,  CAREC  countries’  global  trade  share  remained  at  less  than  1%,4 and  the  lack  of 
intraregional trade, investment, and movement of people made it among the least integrated 
regions in Asia and the Pacific.5 Trade costs are high in the CAREC region: documentary 
compliance cost an average of $190 for export and $275 for import in 2019;6 and significant border 
delays yielded an average border-crossing time of 16.7 hours in 2018.7 In 2018, 8 of the 11 
CAREC countries ranked in the bottom half of the World Bank’s logistics performance index.8

reduction. The CCC platform identifies and addresses issues of mutual concern for CAREC customs agencies and

2      
 
4.  CAREC customs agencies are vital players in increasing trade, improving competitiveness, 
and ensuring the smooth flow of goods and people across borders. Major challenges to the 
efficient rapid transport and transit of goods include inadequate border facilities; nontransparent, 
complex, and excessive procedures at border-crossing points; and weak coordination of border 
agencies at national and cross-border levels. CAREC countries should modernize physical 
border-crossing  point  infrastructure  and  older  border-control  facilities,  which  cannot 
accommodate new transport and trading models (just-in-time manufacturing, vendor-managed 
inventory, and multimodal transport). Customs procedures often cannot keep up with increasingly 
complex trading rules and the tremendous increase in trade volume from increasing international 
e-commerce. 
 
5.  CAREC  customs’  slow  adaptation  to  modern  technology  solutions  perpetuates 
cumbersome paper-based clearance procedures at the border instead of developing paperless 
trade systems, in line with international best practice.9 Suboptimal uptake of single window 
systems and business-to-customs and customs-to-customs data exchange systems prevents fast, 
efficient, and secure trade growth and potential use of blockchain processes. Outdated risk 
management systems are not yet in line with international best practice and hinder efforts of the 
eight CAREC World Trade Organization (WTO) member countries to meet their international 
commitments under the WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement. The relatively low use of national 
authorized economic operator (AEO) programs, often because of inadequate automated customs 
systems and a lack of incentives for the private sector, makes border-crossing points more costly 
and time-consuming.10 Inefficient risk management systems are compounded by the region’s 
underdeveloped transit systems, which hinder member countries’ ability to move cargo rapidly 
and securely and participate in global supply chains. Such factors especially challenge landlocked 
countries.  Border  management  cooperation  has  developed  slowly,  often  because  of  the 
complexities of interagency coordination at national and regional levels, including agreement on 
mutual recognition arrangements to help customs provide better services to the private sector. 
Given  the  prevailing  challenges,  healthy  customs-to-customs  and  business-to-customs 
relationships cannot operate at optimal levels. 
 
6.  Previous ADB TA support has helped address bottlenecks to trade through focused 
interventions, including support to the CCC, a dynamic catalyst in facilitating reform that has 
helped reduce (i) delays caused by 100% physical inspection of goods and transit convoys, (ii) 
manual and multiple submission of document requirements, and (iii) complex, nontransparent 
clearance procedures (footnote 3). CAREC customs have begun adopting international best 
practice to simplify procedures, introduce risk management, and minimize documentation through 
automation. ADB TA has (i) introduced innovative customs–private sector dialogue to identify 
ground-level issues and foster partnerships and (ii) conducted scoping work for investment 
projects that help CAREC governments improve physical infrastructure and build national single 
windows at borders.11 Reforms require continued development, however, to ensure that rapid 
technology innovations do not diminish the benefits they have brought. 
 
 
9  UNESCAP. 2016. United Nations Framework Agreement on Facilitation of Cross-border Paperless Trade in Asia

3      
 
7.  At the 18th Meeting of the CCC (in June 2019 in Tashkent, Uzbekistan), CAREC customs 
agencies requested ADB to continue support for their trade facilitation modernization and reform 
efforts, in particular to (i) improve the capacity of customs to build a regulatory environment that 
promotes efficient, transparent, and modern customs to better serve the private sector; (ii) help 
meet their obligations under the WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement; (iii) implement improved 
regional transit procedures; (iv) intensify efforts to develop and implement effective AEO systems; 
and (v) help identify and prepare trade facilitation investment projects. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: the trade and smooth flow of goods and 
people across the CAREC region increased (footnote 2), and trade from increased market access 
expanded (footnote 1). The TA will have the following outcome: CAREC customs agencies and 
the CCC providing better services to their clients.12  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output  1:  Scoping  studies  with  actionable  recommendations  in  customs 
infrastructure, facilities, use of technology, and logistics support prepared. The TA will 
support scoping studies at select border-crossing points to assess the adequacy of physical 
infrastructure (including laboratory, inspection, and cargo handling facilities); use of information 
and communications technology (including the single window); and logistics support capacities to 
meet international standards and client demand for quality border-crossing services; and to better 
inform  necessary  customs  reforms.  The  TA  will  assess  completed  and  ongoing  regional 
improvement of border services (RIBS) projects to ensure lessons learned are applied to new 
RIBS investments.  
 
10.  Output 2: Initiatives in modern customs technologies and best practice supported. 
The TA will support digital transformation of customs technologies by promoting development of 
e-customs systems, paperless trade, and technology innovations to eliminate trade-hindering 
paper-based  procedures.  It  will  promote  use  of  modern  risk  management  systems  (AEO 
programs)  in  more  CAREC  countries  and  encourage  emerging  AEO  programs  to  develop 
preliminary mutual recognition processes across borders. Participating countries will implement 
the comprehensive, risk-based CAREC Advanced Transit System (CATS) to enhance supply 
chain security, help trade flow more smoothly, and reduce costs; CATS will be supported by a 
customs information common exchange to facilitate intra- and extra-regional trade.13 
 
11.  Output 3: Customs capacity improved. The TA will help conduct technical skills training 
and adoption of measures to reduce delay at border-crossing points, such as expanded joint 
customs border control pilots and regular customs–private sector dialogue. The TA will help 
develop business-to-customs and customs-to-customs electronic platforms and encourage study 
visits and inter-subregional learning opportunities to optimize lessons learned from other customs’ 
and private sector experience. The TA will enhance customs’ capacity to better cope with 
increasing  volumes  of  trade  (arising  from  e-commerce,  blockchain  application,  and  other 
technology innovations) and coordinate joint training on logistics management and coordinated 
border management with border agencies and the private sector. The TA will draw on and

strengthen ADB’s knowledge partnership for customs cooperation and trade facilitation activities 
with development partners, including but not limited to the CAREC Institute, the United Nations’ 
Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, the World Customs Organization and 
its designated regional training centers such as Shanghai Customs College, and the WTO. 
 
12.  TA outputs reflect CCC priority areas of work and will help implement the CCC 2019–2021 
work plan, aligned with the CITA 2030 Rolling Strategic Action Plan, 2019–2021. The outputs will 
also help the CCC (i) coordinate and maintain dialogue with other CAREC platforms and sectors, 
such as the Regional Trade Group, the CAREC Transport Coordinating Committee, and the 
CAREC Federation of Carrier and Forwarder Association and (ii) identify opportunities for future 
trade-related investment projects. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,450,000, of which (i) $250,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration (RCI) Fund;14 (ii) $500,000 will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  Poverty  Reduction  and  Regional 
Cooperation Fund and administered by ADB;15 and $700,000 will be financed on a grant basis by 
the United Kingdom Fund for Asia Regional Trade and Connectivity (ARTCF) under the Regional 
Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility and administered by ADB. The key 
eligible expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB  will  administer  the  TA.  ADB’s  East  Asia  Department  (EARD)  will  implement, 
supervise, and monitor activities, including procuring equipment, organizing workshops, and 
selecting and managing consultants and resource persons. EARD will manage output 1 of the 
KSTA together with Central and West Asia Transport and Communications division which will 
play a leading role in identifying upstream investments in CWRD countries and translating these 
into operations. EARD will work in coordination with the CAREC unit (Central and West Asia 
Regional  Department); ADB  resident missions;  existing  development partners (the  CAREC 
Institute and Regional Knowledge Sharing Initiative); and others, creating synergies among 
regional initiatives.16 ADB will coordinate implementation of the TA with ongoing regional TA 
efforts to enhance trade performance and ensure mutual complementarity of activities.17 EARD 
will fully comply with monitoring and reporting of activities required under specific funding sources 
and hold regular consultations with funding sources. The implementation arrangements are 
summarized in the table.

15.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.18 The TA will require 24 person-months of international and 24 person-
months of national consultant inputs. ADB will recruit consultants individually rather than through 
a firm because (i) the wide range of experience, expertise, and specific knowledge of the CAREC 
Program and countries required to complete all TA activities is not available in a single firm; and 
(ii) consultants and resource persons should be rapidly mobilized. EARD will manage all individual 
consultants. Where appropriate, ADB will consider output-based contracts for administrative 
efficiency and simplified disbursement. 
 
16.  ADB’s procurement. ADB will procure software and small equipment (three servers) for 
the CATS initiative through requests for quotation and direct contracting. Procurement will be in 
accordance with Asian Development Bank Procurement Policy (2017, as may be amended from 
time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $700,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the United Kingdom Fund for Asia 
Regional Trade and Connectivity under the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing 
Partnership Facility; (ii) ADB administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the 
equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the People's Republic of China Poverty 
Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund; and (iii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the 
equivalent of $250,000 on a grant basis for Better Customs for Better Client Services in Central 
Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Countries, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

  Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Scoping studies with actionable recommendations in customs infrastructure, facilities, use of technology, 
and logistics support prepared 
1.1  Together with CWTC, conduct scoping studies in select BCPs identified as problematic under the CPMM to include: 
adequacy of physical infrastructure (buildings, offices, warehouses, access roads) to accommodate new modes of 
transport and transit; border facilities (inspection and laboratory equipment, and information and communications 
technology facilities, including the single window); logistics support facilities at BCPs (accommodation for drivers, 
provision for food services); and recommendations to address the gaps, including possible investment projects 
(BCP1: Q4 2019–Q3 2020; BCP2: Q3 2020–Q2 2021; and BCP3: Q3 2020–Q2 2021). 
2.  Initiatives in modern customs technologies and best practice supported 
2.1  Support digital transformation by enhancing e-customs systems and new developments in ICT to facilitate trade, 
such as paperless trade, cross border e-commerce, and blockchain technology (Q4 2019–Q1 2021).  
2.2  Support accession to the United Nations’ Framework Agreement on Facilitation of Cross-Border Paperless Trade in 
Asia-Pacific (Q1 2020–Q2 2021) through awareness raising and technical workshops, preparation of frameworks for 
accession and expert assistance. 
2.3. Prepare frameworks and work plans to assist countries in adopting modern risk management systems and 
approaches and develop national AEO programs and preliminary mutual recognition processes for AEOs across 
borders (Q4 2019–Q2 2021). 
2.4.  Provide  technical  assistance  to  implement  the  CAREC  Advanced  Transit  System  Agreement,  based  on 
comprehensive and risk-based guarantees and supported by a customs information common exchange; support 
accession to the Convention on a Common Transit Procedure, and the use of the New Computerized Transit System 
to facilitate trade with European markets (Q4 2019–Q2 2021). 
3. Customs capacity improved 
3.1. To improve services delivered to clients, provide technical skills training to customs, other border agencies, and 
the private sector: study visits and joint trainings on logistics management, coordinated border management, joint 
customs border control electronic data exchange, e-commerce, and blockchain technology (Q1 2020–Q4 2021).  
3.2 Enhance existing and develop new cooperative relationships with private sector and other stakeholders through joint 
trainings, research activities, policy dialogues on border-crossing issues based on CPMM results, and adoption of 
standards (Q1 2020-Q3 2020). 
3.3 Strengthen coordination with other trade sector cooperative mechanisms such as the CAREC RTG, CAREC 
Transport Sector Coordinating Committee, and CAREC Institute; organize annual meeting of CCC and joint meeting 
with RTG (Q2 2020-Q2 2021). 
3.4 Enhance inter-subregional learning opportunities for CAREC countries with other ADB subregional platforms, e.g., 
South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (Q4 2019–Q4 2020). 
TA Management Activities 
Conduct supervision assessment missions; consult with customs agencies and the private sector to ensure smooth 
implementation of the TA; coordinate with other development partners to avoid duplication and maximize sustainable 
development outcomes; and provide technical and administrative guidance to ensure efficient implementation of the TA.
